big_picture_notes: Proverbs is a divinely inspired anthology—multiple curated collections whose superscriptions provide the text‑driven framework. Its governing poetic device is parallelism (antithetical, synonymous, and synthetic), and its thematic center is 1:7: 'The fear of the LORD is the beginning of knowledge.' The book moves from extended, thematic discourses (chs. 1–9) to dense couplets (10:1–22:16), to 'sayings of the wise' akin to ANE instruction (22:17–24:34), to a Hezekian Solomonic appendix (25–29), and concludes with Agur (30) and Lemuel (31). For memorization, treat each discrete discourse or themed proverb cluster as a scene; do not arbitrarily split complete poems.

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Chs. 1–9 form an extended prologue of longer poems/discourses, contrasting Lady Wisdom and Folly. Start (1:1) titles the anthology; the section begins with 1:8 ('My son...') and ends at 9:18 with Folly's fatal feast, parallel to Wisdom's invitation (9:1–6). Literary Glue: repeated 'My son' addresses and the personifications of Wisdom and Folly.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Title (1:1) + purpose (1:2-6) conclude with the thematic key (1:7): 'The fear of the LORD...'—a complete thesis for the book.

scenes.scene_name: A Father's Warning: The Call of Sinners
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Begins 'My son' (1:8); ends with summary (1:19). A single narrative warning against violent greed, juxtaposing enticement and self‑destruction.
New speaker/location (1:20). Prophetic‑style monologue: confrontation, warning, threat of abandonment, and a closing promise of security (v. 33).

scenes.scene_name: The Quest for Wisdom and its Protection
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: One long 'if... then...' poem: seeking (1–4) → understanding from the LORD (5–8) → moral formation (9–11) → deliverance from evil man/woman (12–22).
'My son' imperatives (do not forget, trust, honor, accept discipline) each paired with a promise, concluding with the rationale for discipline (v. 12).
Beatitude on finding wisdom (13–15), her life‑giving benefits (16–18), and her cosmic role with God in creation (19–20).
Practical results: personal safety (21–26) and social righteousness (27–32), closing with destinies of wise vs. wicked (33–35).
Nested voice: father cites his father's instruction—'Get wisdom' (vv. 5,7)—closing with rewards (v. 9).
Path metaphor contrasts righteous dawn (11–13,18) vs. wicked darkness (14–17,19), forming balanced inclusio.

scenes.scene_name: Guard Your Heart: The Fount of Life
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Body‑part integrity poem—ear, eyes, heart, mouth/lips, feet—with v. 23 as hinge: 'Keep your heart with all vigilance.'
'My son' warning contrasts honeyed lips of the stranger with bitter end; concludes with ruin cry (v. 14).
Positive counter‑poem: drink from your own cistern; public/private springs; the LORD's omniscience (v. 21) and the sinner's cords (v. 22).
Composite scene of four complete units: surety (1–5), sluggard (6–11), worthless man (12–15), and the 'seven abominations' list (16–19).
Parents' commands guard (20–23); vivid fire/wounds imagery warns of inescapable consequences and jealous vengeance (27–35).

scenes.scene_name: The Seduction of the Simple Youth
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Unified narrative: setup (1–9), woman's appearance/speech (10–21), youth's fall (22–23), global warning (24–27).
Counter‑speech to ch. 7: public summons to all (1–11); wisdom's character and riches/righteousness rewards (12–21).

scenes.scene_name: Wisdom from Everlasting and in Creation
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Wisdom before (22–26) and during creation (27–31) leading to appeal and life/death choice (32–36).

scenes.scene_name: The Feasts of Wisdom and Folly
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Balanced finale: Wisdom's feast (1–6), hinge proverbs on scoffer/wise (7–12), Folly's counterfeit feast leading to Sheol (13–18).

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Primary Solomonic couplets collection marked by 10:1 ('The proverbs of Solomon') and ending at 22:16 before a new heading (22:17). Literary Glue: pervasive antithetical parallelism and thematic contrasts (wise/foolish, righteous/wicked, diligent/slothful, wealth/poverty).

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Introduces son motif and outcomes of righteousness/wickedness, concluding with 'memory of the righteous' vs. 'name of the wicked' (v. 7).
Wise of heart vs. babbling fool; walking secure vs. perverse ways; lips of the wise store knowledge vs. mouth of the foolish is ruin.

scenes.scene_name: Wealth, Labor, and the LORD's Blessing
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Contrasts wealth/poverty alongside righteousness/path of life; resolves with 'The blessing of the LORD makes rich' (v. 22).

scenes.scene_name: The Fool, the Wise, and the Fear of the LORD
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Fool's sport vs. wisdom, whirlwind vs. foundation, with hinge 'The fear of the LORD prolongs life' (v. 27), closing with speech summary (v. 32).
False balances vs. just weights; pride vs. humility; integrity vs. crookedness, culminating in righteous deliverance (v. 8).

scenes.scene_name: The Righteous City vs. The Wicked City
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: City rejoices at righteous welfare and falls under wicked rule (vv. 10–11); warnings on talebearing and surety bind the social theme.
Gracious vs. ruthless, merciful vs. cruel, deceitful vs. sure reward; caps with desires of righteous vs. wicked (v. 23).

stories.story_title: The Thirty Sayings of the Wise
stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: New headings at 22:17 ('Incline your ear to the words of the wise') and 24:23 ('These also are sayings of the wise') mark a distinct curated collection. Style shifts from couplets to multi‑line sayings akin to ANE instruction (cf. Amenemope).

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Introduction stating purpose: to make you know 'words of truth' for right answers (v. 21).

scenes.scene_name: Saying 1: Do Not Rob the Poor
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Two‑verse admonition with divine advocacy: the LORD will plead the poor's cause.
Avoid the hot‑tempered lest you learn his ways and ensnare your soul.
Warning against pledges: why should your bed be taken from under you?

scenes.scene_name: Saying 4: Do Not Move the Landmark
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Single‑verse protection of ancestral boundaries—social stability and justice.

scenes.scene_name: Saying 5: The Diligent in the Presence of Kings
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: A single‑verse observation—skill brings one before rulers.
Etiquette and caution—discern appetite and deceitful delicacies.

scenes.scene_name: Saying 7: Do Not Wear Yourself to Get Rich
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Wealth's fleeting wings; set not your eyes on it.
Do not eat the bread of a miser; his heart is not with you—your pleasant words return to you.

scenes.scene_name: Saying 9: Do Not Speak in the Hearing of a Fool
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Single verse—he will despise the wisdom of your words.
Move not the ancient landmark; Redeemer is strong and will plead their cause.
Supplemental heading (24:23). Approve the right, rebuke the wicked—'right answer' wins a kiss (v. 26).
Observation (30–31) → reflection (32) → conclusion (33–34): poverty comes like a robber.

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Explicit editorial title at 25:1; style returns to clustered couplets with many similes/comparisons and court‑wisdom. Concludes the fourth major collection at 29:27.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: God's glory to conceal, kings' to search; remove dross/wicked; counsel on presence before rulers.
Do not hasten to court; a word fitly spoken as apples of gold; persuasion by patience.
Twelve similes on the fool (1–12) followed by four on the sluggard (13–16)—two vivid character studies.
Contentious meddler, talebearer fuel, burning lips and wicked heart—coherent warning against quarrel and deceit.

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Ch. 30 stands as a self‑contained appendix by Agur son of Jakeh, featuring confessional humility, prayer for moderation, and a series of numerical proverbs.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Title (30:1); confession of limited wisdom (2–4) and twofold prayer—keep falsehood far, give neither poverty nor riches (7–9).
Brief warning (v. 10) followed by 'There is a generation...' catalogue of four wicked types.
Horseleech preface; 'three... four...' list of the insatiable; eye that mocks parents meets judgment.

scenes.scene_name: Four Wonderful and Four Unbearable Things
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Two numerical units: wondrous ways (18–19) and intolerable inversions (21–23), with v. 20 framing the adulterous woman.

scenes.scene_name: Four Small but Wise, and Four Stately Things
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Four wise small creatures (24–28), four stately ones (29–31), concluding counsel against stirring anger (32–33).

stories.story_title: The Words of Lemuel and The Excellent Wife
stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Ch. 31 is the closing appendix attributed to King Lemuel: his mother's oracle on kingship (31:1–9) followed by the acrostic 'excellent wife' (31:10–31). Literary Glue: alphabetic acrostic binding the final poem and thematic fear‑of‑the‑LORD center.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Maternal counsel: avoid women and strong drink (3–7); open your mouth for the mute and needy (8–9).

scenes.scene_name: The Excellent Wife: Value and Work (Aleph–Kaph)
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Acrostic begins—her worth above jewels (10–12) and diligent domestic industry (13–15).

scenes.scene_name: The Excellent Wife: Enterprise and Strength (Lamedh–Pe)
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Field purchase, profitable lamp, girded strength; clothing and household provisioning (16–22).

scenes.scene_name: The Excellent Wife: Character and Praise (Tsadhe–Taw)
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Husband's honor, wise speech, kindness; children and husband praise; beauty fades but fear of the LORD endures; works praised in the gates.
